Additional Info: Sierra Club Cover Letter & Cert. of Service - Reply Brief
content:
May 29, 2025  
Via Email 
The Honorable Megan McKenzie  
Office of Administrative Hearings  
600 N. Robert Street  
Saint Paul, MN 55164- 020 
 
RE:  In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
PUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198, M -24-383 / OAH Docket No. 25- 2500- 40339 
 
Dear Judge McKenzie:  
 Enclosed and e -filed in the above -referenced matter please find the following documents filed on 
behalf of Sierra Club:  
 
• Public Redacted  Post -Hearing  Reply  Brief  
• Limited Distribution Highly Confidential Trade Secret Post -Hearing Reply Brief  (Not for 
distribution to ALLETE)  
 
By copy of this letter all parties have been served. A Certificate of Service is also enclosed.  
 
Sincerely,  
 
___/s/ Patrick Woolsey __________  
 Kristin Henry  
Patrick Woolsey  
Sierra Club Environmental Law Program  
2101 Webster Street Suite 1300 Oakland, CA  94612  
(415) 977- 5757  
kristin.henry@sierraclub.org patrick.woolsey@sierraclub.org  Evan Mulholland Minnesota Center for Environmental Advocacy  
1919 University Ave. W #515 St. Paul, MN 55104  
(651) 223- 5969  
emulholland@mncenter.org  Attorneys for Sierra Club 
 

Certificate of Service  
I, Joaquin Garcia, certify that, on M ay 29, 2025, I submitted, by electronic filing, Sierra 
Club’s Public Redacted  Post -Hearing  Reply  Brief  and Sierra Club’s Limited Distribution Highly 
Confidential Trade Secret Post -Hearing Reply Brief  in the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners PUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198, M -24-383 / OAH Docket No. 25 -
2500- 40339, and electronically serve d it on all parties included in the official service list for this 
docket.  
/s/ Joaquin Garcia _  
Joaquin Garcia  
Sierra Club Environmental Law Program  
2101 Webster Street Suite 1300  
Oakland, CA 94612  
(415) 977- 5629  
joaquin.garcia@sierraclub.org

 INTRODUCTION 
Sierra Club and other intervenors in this proceeding (“Intervenors”) have presented 
extensive evidence showing that the proposed acquisition  (“Acquisition”) of ALLETE, Inc.  by 
Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”) and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board  (“CPP”) 
(together, the “Partners”) would provide no benefits to ratep ayers and poses extensive harms and 
risks: it may threaten Minnesota Power’s ( the “Company ”) compliance with the Carbon Free 
Standard, does not guarantee access to capital, is likely to contribute to dramatically higher 
rates,1 and would result in loss of local control and reduced transparency. Petitioners repeatedly 
claim without evidence that the Acquisition  would not cause any harms and is sure to provide 
benefits . But most of the alleged benefits are unenforceable statements of intention, not firm 
commitments, or are simply descriptions of the existing status quo or existing regulatory requirements, and thus not benefits at all. Petitioners attempt to dismiss the likely harms of the Acquisition  as uncertain and speculative, but the numerous pot ential harms and r isks raised by 
multiple Intervenors are based on credible evidence, including evidence provided by Petitioners 
themselves. T he Commission  must consider the magnitude and likelihood of those risks.  
Petitioners also argue that there is no n eed to worry about the Acquisition ’s harmful effects 
because the Commission will retain the ability to review the Company’s future actions in rate cases and Integrated Resource Plan proceedings. But while the Commission ’s review of this 
transaction and of the Company’s future decision -making is critically  important to protect 
ratepayers, Commission review cannot eliminate every risk posed by the Acquisition . Petitioners 
claim that access to capital is the primary benefit of the Ac quisition , but i f the Acquisition  is

ARGUMENT  
I. PETITIONERS FAIL TO  MEET THEIR BURDEN U NDER THE 
APPLICABLE LEGAL STANDARD. 
Petitioners ’ opening briefs2 ignore an essential aspect of the legal standard governing 
Commission review of the proposed transaction: Petitioners bear the burden of proof to show 
that the Acquisition  meets the public interest standard  under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, subd. 1.3 
Intervenors have presented evidence that the Acquisition  is inconsistent with the public interest, 
but Intervenors do not bear the burden of proof. R ather, P etitioners must demonstrate that  the 
Acquisition  is consistent with the public interest. P etitioners fail to  meet th at burden. 
Petitioners also argue that the Commission should not consider whether the Acquisition  
would have net benefits.4 On the contrary, Commission precedent makes clear that t he 
Commission  can—and should—c onsider whether the Acquisition  would provide affirmative net 
benefit s.5 Because Petitioners assert that the acquisition is necessary for the Company to comply

Moreover, even if a showing of affirmative net benefit were  not required, the proposed 
Acquisition  still fails to meet the public interest standard because evidence shows that its likely

evidence of concrete benefit s sufficient to counter- balance the transaction’s likely harms. 
Petitioners have not shown that the Acquisition will not result in net harms, or rebutt ed 
Intervenors’ evidence showing that net harms are likely to occur.  
Finally, the Company appears to suggest that because the Federal Energy Regulatory

 II. PETITIONERS HAVE NOT  DEMONSTRATED THAT THE ACQUISITION 
WOULD HELP THE COMPANY COMPLY WITH THE CARBON FREE 
STANDARD.  
Petitioners offer no evidence for their repeated claims that the Acquisition  would 
facilitate the Company’s compliance with the Carbon Free Standard. As Witness Lane explained , 
the evidence shows that the Acquisition  may not help —and could in fact undermine—t he 
Company’s compliance with the Carbon Free Standard because the Partner s have not committed 
to fund renewable energy, could seek to delay  the retirement dates for the coal- fired Boswell 
Generating Station, and could s ell the C ompany before it achieves the Standard.10  
Petitioners  claim that these concerns are speculative and not based on evidence.11 But the 
record contains concrete evidence substantiating each of these concerns, including documents 
showing the Partners’  lack of commitment to long -term ownership of ALLETE,12 and evidence

A. The Partners Have Not Committed to Fund Renewable Energy.  
The Partners assert that they plan to fund the Company’s clean energy transition, and the 
Company repeatedly claims that the Partners have made explicit commitments to invest in 
renewable infrastructure.15 On the contrary, the Partners have not made a firm commitment to 
provide any amount of capital directed specifically to renewable energy.16 No such commitment 
is contained anywhere in the Acquisition  terms or in the list of commitments provided by 
Petitione rs.17 In support of its claims that the Partners have committed to fund clean energy, the 
Company repeatedly cites to page 25 of Witness Bram ’s Rebuttal testimony.18 But Witness 
Bram ’s testimony contains no such commitment: page 25 of Witness Bram’s Rebuttal simply 
asserts the Partners’ general desire to comply with the Carbon Free Standard.19 
The Partners’ generalized statements of intention  or investment philosophy in their pre -
filed testimony are unenforceable. They are no substitute for a n enforceable,  concrete 
commitment to provide a minimum amount of capital specifically for renewable energy projects . 
That commitment is absent from Petitioners’ proposal. While Alloy Parent commits to provide 
equity financing for  the Company’s 5-year capital plan , that commitment is not made by the 
Partners.20 Nor does that commitment guarantee how much capital Alloy Parent will provide for

CONCLUSION  
Petitioners have not met their burden to show that the Acquisition  is consistent with the 
public interest. They have not demonstrated that the Acquisition  would provide benefits 
sufficient to outweigh its  substantial harms and risks, or that their proposed commitments would 
adequately mitigate these harms and risks.  The Commission should not approve the Acquisition .

content:
This message may be from an external email source.
Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT Services Security
Operations Center.From: Ryan Bishop (MP)
To: Staff, CAO (PUC)
Subject: PUC Docket Number 24-198
Date: Thursday, April 17, 2025 1:25:19 PM
You don't often get email from rbishop@mnpower.com. Learn why this is important
Good Afternoon,
 I would like to voice my support for the acquisition of ALLETE by CPP Investments and GIP. I have been a Minnesota Power employee for over 16 years and am proud to work for a company thatsupports a culture of service in the community.  ALLETE is, and will continue to be, a strong andvaluable member of the community with this acquisition. This acquisition will help position ALLETE to continue the transition to meet the state’s sustainabilityrequirements while providing safe and reliable energy to customers.  It provides the necessaryaccess to capital needed to meet these requirements.  Minnesota Power will continue to be aregulated utility and accountable to the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission and our customers. I believe this acquisition is in the best interest of ALLETE, our customers, and our community. Thank you,Ryan Bishop
